content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials. Grants will be awarded to expand opportunities for scientists and researchers, as well as promote the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in the health professions. Support for institutions in underrepresented communities for workforce development. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities that focus on health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving institutions, tribal colleges, and institutions with programs for minority health professionals. Entities eligible for grants include Hispanic-serving institutions, tribal colleges and universities, Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions, institutions with programs for underrepresented minority health professionals, health professional associations, and institutions located in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations. These entities must have partnerships to increase workforce diversity and enroll at least 20% underrepresented minorities. Entities eligible for grants must have partnerships to increase workforce diversity and enroll at least 20% underrepresented minorities. Amounts received under a grant shall be used to expand, implement, or evaluate workforce diversity programs, including mental health care professions. Possible activities include educational outreach programs and scholarship programs. Possible activities to enhance diversity in healthcare professions include educational outreach programs, scholarship programs, postbaccalaureate programs, academic enrichment programs, mentoring programs, internship programs, community partnership development, and leadership training. Grantees must submit annual reports summarizing and evaluating their workforce diversity initiatives. The grantee must submit annual reports summarizing and evaluating activities related to workforce diversity, including community partnership development and leadership training. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. SEC. 5. ELIMINATING DISPARITIES IN MATERNITY HEALTH OUTCOMES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various healthcare organizations, will conduct research and expand access to services to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services aims to address disparities in maternal care and health outcomes by expanding access to proven services and conducting a demonstration project in up to 8 states to compare and implement effective interventions. States will be selected based on specified regions and populations to ensure representativeness. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a demonstration project in up to 8 states to address maternal care disparities. States will be selected based on specified regions and populations. The project will test various models with existing evidence-based interventions and involve local provider organizations. The project will run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. The demonstration project, starting in 2015 and ending in 2019, involves local provider organizations like community health centers and hospital systems. Grants may be given for data collection, and participating states must report project outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care to the Secretary. The Secretary requires data on project outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care for monitoring and evaluation. A final report on the demonstration project results must be submitted to Congress by December 31, 2020. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about racial and ethnic disparities in health care. This program will disseminate scientific evidence and implement outreach campaigns to reduce these disparities. The health disparities education program aims to raise awareness about racial and ethnic disparities in healthcare, disseminate new research findings, and address linguistic and cultural barriers in healthcare quality. The program aims to assist providers and patients in understanding and reducing health disparities, disseminate information about linguistic and cultural barriers in healthcare, educate providers on disparities, and assess the impact of these initiatives. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. The program aims to reduce health disparities, educate providers, and assess the impact of initiatives. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
